Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2011 02:49PM Lena wrote: Geez. I can't help but ask here...what if the person complaining about joint aches or other seemingly minor issues is a Stage IV patient experiencing those things as side effects from treatment? As in the joint aches are from AIs, chemo, biphosphonates or Neulasta, or the sore throat, even if it's just as temporary as the sore throat you get from a cold, is from radiation treatment to the subclavicular nodes, the rash is an allergic reaction to taxotere or the weight gain is from decadron, hormonal treatment or ascites? I don't need to question, and I also sometimes get irritated when otherwise known healthy people (who do not have cancer or other serious/terminal illnesses), frequently complain about minor to moderate symptoms -- which will be cured in a few days or a couple of weeks by their own otherwise well functioning immune systems or a couple of days or maybe a week taking a medicine which has no side effects worse than a little sleepiness which goes away as soon as the medicine is stopped/the condition gone; or can be fixed FAIRLY easily by diet and exercise). In those cases, yup, I DO sometimes think, "Hey, I'll trade you your cold/flu/stomach bug/eczema rash/30 extra pounds for my metastatic breast cancer." One of these days maybe I'll have the opportunity (and the nerve) to say that. LOL However, some of the things I'm reading here rather irk me, but since this is apparently a venting thread -- which we all NEED, it's all good and thanks in advance for letting me join you in venting. So my irked reaction begs the question: Before you all were diagnosed, weren't your priorities a little different? We might roll our eyes NOW at the idea of an otherwise normal and healthy person who complains that his or her sprained ankle means s/he has to cancel his/her originally planned long weekend hiking or biking trip, or someone who calls in sick to work because of a stuffy/runny nose with or without a sore throat (and nothing else), but can't you remember your life BEFORE the shit hit the fan? I remember one particular year (years prior to my diagnosis and like the majority of mostly healthy women in their 30s it never even occurred to me I might someday get breast cancer, much less METASTATIC breast cancer), agonizing, since money was always tight for me, over the decision about what that year's "expensive treat" would be -- "Should I buy the DVD player and Star Trek original series on DVD, or do I spend the money for the Oktobertrek convention where I have to pay for a hotel room and eating out, not to mention whatever else I might want to buy there?"  Well really now, that can't possibly compare to, and in fact sounds really silly compared to, the kinds of decisions we've all had to make and questions we've all had to consider as Stage IV patients. Some of my recent ones have been, "Do I agree with my onc and BS that radiation treatment will postpone the return of the skin mets?" and once having agreed, "Can I believe the RO when she says and that all I'll get is a little tired which an afternoon nap will fix, and a pink, slightly sore/sensitive chest?" or "What's next; should I try Faslodex or go into the suggested clinical trial for Tykerb on HER2- patients?" or how about this one:  "I have Stage IV inflammatory breast cancer and it is DEFINITE that I'm going to die from it sooner or later ANYWAY. All of the treatments I've had thus far which have let me live longer, save one, have had such horrific SEs as to make life not worth living. Isn't it time to stop this miserable gambling already, call the palliative folks, and be able to enjoy at least most of whatever time I have left?" SOOOO....I guess the fact that there was no way I would have been able to work while (1) I had constant crushing fatigue and serious cognitive deficits while doing 6 rounds of TAC that took two months to even START to go away; (2) I found it excruciatingly painful to get up from or sit down on a chair or the toilet, developed serious pain in one of my shoulders which would only abate with narcotic painkillers until of all doctors, my PCP finally sent me to an orthopedic specialist for a cortisone shot and had near suicidal depression and continuing cognitive deficits while taking AIs and (3) I consider my entire summer ruined because the RO was way too positive about how "easy" rads would be, especially compared to chemo. (yes, chemo fatigue WAS a lot worse but rads fatigue was only marginally better; I still needed to spend nearly half the day on the couch, plus had to live on Dayquil and Nyquil to stop the intense coughing fits and topped it off with blistering second degree burns on my whole chest) -- and (4) in the two and a half YEARS since I've been diagnosed I've only had ONE interval which lasted six WEEKS during which I actually felt GOOD and that I question why with THAT kind of ratio I should be HAPPY to be alive -- this all makes me a lazy whining bitch, right? OK fine, then that's what I am. And what in the hell is this "grateful" and "ungrateful" shit all about? I am unable to comprehend that one at all. To whom should anybody be grateful and to whom is anybody ungrateful with regards to this horrible disease which none of us signed up for or deserves to have? EEEEESH. This is so ridiculous! Thanks so much for starting this thread Jan, and to you all for listening to me vent also.

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2011 10:47PM Lena wrote: I drank Ensure occasionally when I was on chemo. Well maybe a little more than occasionally... In prepping for chemo, I originally bought three 6-packs of Ensure for "just in case" and in the four months I had chemo (6 rounds of TAC April through July 2009) I actually DID drink them all up. In fact, I also drank the three MORE 6-packs of it I bought when my Pack Rat took me shopping and carried the heavy stuff. My problem with "real" food wasn't (usually) actual loss of appetite, it was a combination of: wrecked taste buds and this horrible constant foul taste in my mouth, I called it Sewer Mouth (not metallic though, and it was so bad that even though I brushed my teeth with Biotene toothpaste and used Biotene mouthwash too, I could only get rid of it for 5 minutes at a time tops). And also, worse than foods not TASTING right was how many foods didn't FEEL right anymore either. Bread for instance. I had originally thought I'd probably eat a lot of sandwiches (and slices of toast) while on chemo since they're nice light meals and easy to make -- a good thing when you know you're going to be totally wiped and NOT in the mood to cook (or worse, wash dishes) a lot -- but bread felt like cardboard in my mouth, and was totally inedible until several weeks after I finished chemo. But, I digress. My other problem besides food taste/texture issues was not so much loss of appetite or nausea (I faithfully took my anti-nausea meds and they worked), but rather one of being too tired to cook what few foods I still LIKED to eat, and dreading making meals because I didn't want to clean up after them, and also sometimes because even food I liked just didn't sound good anymore either...so I'd drink a bottle of Ensure, instead.  Most of the time I was on chemo I DID eat SOMETHING solid or semi-solid once or twice a day, like maybe 75-80% of the time, but yeah, there were definitely some times I just didn't want to be BOTHERED with actually cooking and eating. As to my weight on chemo -- I neither gained nor lost -- I fluctuated a little up and down so therefore ended up staying the same. (It was the AIs that made me gain weight! but I went on a diet and now weigh about 8 pounds less than when I was on chemo! Yay!)

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2011 08:11PM - edited Jul 13, 2011 08:28PM by Lena Gotta admit I didn't really "choose" no recon as much as the cancer chose for me, BUT at least there's ONE good thing about it: NO FRICKIN BRAS EVER AGAIN!!! I was told to wear a sports bra by a nurse in the surgery department and I did go so far as to buy one just prior to my BMX, but when I tried to put it on maybe 3-4 weeks postop/done with most of the chest pain, thanks to my stroke I didn't have the motor coordination to hook it (yes it was a front closure BTW) and as soon as I got major pissed off and burst into tears and a curse myself out fest about not being able to hook it closed or figure out a workaround to do it despite my left hand paralysis, I also suddenly thought: "I don't even HAVE breasts anymore -- so what the f*** do I need a BRA for?!" I don't!! And I've been totally fine without one. The Chest continues to heal up, and I finished PT so I got back the range of motion I lost from the surgery. I'm not up to carrying heavy loads (or even just big and bulky) but I couldn't do that before the surgery either; between my bad back and the stroke it's been decades since I could do that kind of thing anyway. Which means, and I'm coming up on 8 weeks postop: I'm "back to normal" -- at least as far as surgical recovery and ability to do things I had been doing prior to the operation goes. LOL So the sports bra ended up with all my other bras from when I had breasts: in the pile of stuff to be given to the thrift shop, when I finally get around to doing THAT.    ETA: Shippy -- I was able to do laundry 3 weeks postop using the "lower" dryers in the laundromat (couldn't raise my arms enough to use the upper ones which I like better until maybe 5-6 weeks postop). I think it was also 5-6 weeks postop or thereabouts when I was able to clear the kitchen table of all the "supplies" which normally live in cabinets and just get things in and out of cabinets, as well as resume using the "high" dryers. I haven't yet done a MAJOR grocery shopping trip since surgery (which was on 5/20/11) but that's mostly because I haven't HAD to. I normally keep REALLY stocked up so I only need to pick up some milk, eggs, fresh fruit and salad stuff about every week and a half --SERIOUS grocery shopping is usually about every two months. I've had no problems with these little pickups, not other than my own laziness at least: when I get off my butt and go, I don't have any problems. However, seeing how rads are coming up I'd like to do a bigger run, particularly since it times well with the fact that I also have to get the fresh fruits and veggies. But, it's my own laziness/fatigue slowing me down now (my GI tract attacked me 4th of July weekend so I've been really ill), not fearing a lack of ability to do it once I get off my lazy butt.

Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2011 11:32PM - edited Jun 20, 2011 11:34PM by Lena Ummmm hmmmmm.... Even though I was perimenopausal when I was diagnosed, I hadn't had any hot flashes naturally -- I only got them once I started chemo...which pushed me the rest of the way off the menopause cliff. It was April 2009 when I started chemo, July when I finished, and at the time I lived in an upstairs apartment so it would get hot in the summer there ANYWAY. So for that whole summer (and the subsequent one, which was last summer), I had to run the ACs (one in the living room, one in the bedroom) full blast. The hot flashes -- yes horrible -- always starting with heart palpitations and shortness of breath (so I always know when they're coming, too) not only were severely superheating, but so bad my Pack Rat could feel my body temperature rising if we were in physical contact. Hahaha, in the winter he says he wishes I could make them come on command. Buuut... They started maybe 3 weeks to a month into chemo, continued all the way through chemo, then kept on going through 5 months of Tamoxifen. I had a serious complication from the Tamoxifen (a deep vein thrombosis) so was taken off it and put on AIs. Hot flashes kept going and going and going strong all the way through almost a year and a half of AIs. I just came off the last AI two months ago and while all the other AI side effects have abated, I do still get hot flashes. Now, they're not as bad and not as frequent as they were while I was having chemo and taking anti-estrogen medications, but I still get anywhere from 3-5 per day, every day, and one or two every night. SSRIs cause me sexual side effects I refuse to tolerate (I needed treatment for depression, which I got thanks to chemo and then AIs made it worse); the only antidepressant I can take is Wellbutrin, so no Effexor for me. A friend of mine had suggested black cohosh, and my onc at the time said he didn't think it would work but no harm to try it. I tried it for three months and no, it didn't work. From late April 2009 when they started up until about a month ago when they started slowing down a bit, EVERYTHING seemed to be a trigger. The worst ones were the ones I'd get while falling asleep (I would be in bed or lying on the couch, dozing into sleep for the night or an afternoon nap and as soon as I thought I was "gone," whammo! power surge!). Oh, and this "trigger" has pissed me off repeatedly from the get-go: five minutes after I get out of the shower and feel clean in clean clothes -- whammo and I'm all gross feeling hot and sweaty again, like WHY did I just take a freakin' shower? And, unlike the rest of you who mention it, exercise GIVES me hot flashes, it doesn't make them go away. It never fails -- every time I get home from a walk (my main form of exercise) I'm "dying" of overheating! I used to have to strip off my clothes and jump in a cold shower to get relief (for a little while anyway). Even though they're milder now (I usually only have to change into a tank top and shorts), I still come home from my walks and the instant I sit down -- whammo! And I still get the trying to go to sleep ones. They still ruin most of my naps but at least I manage to fall asleep most of the time at night (once I kick the covers off)....I guess it's the sleeping pills.

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2010 09:52AM Lena wrote: I'm over a year out from diagnosis (Stage IV out of the gate) but I've NEVER gotten to "dance with NED." And geez, the "only" mets I had at diagnosis were the mediastinal nodes and left iliac bone. Chemo cleared up the nodes, but it only REDUCED my breast tumor and bone met, and even on hormonal therapy (which for me is ALMOST as bad as chemo was!) I can still feel tumor in my right breast, so I figure the best I'll ever do is have an affair with the stable boy. I thought I was on to that but now i'm not sure if or how long the affair with the stable boy will last: my oncologist said, about my last scans (June), that the PET showed POSSIBLE evidence of a lung met but the CT showed NO evidence of one, but since I have no symptoms, he'll just order more scans in September and we'll see how it goes. Oh, and I've been on SS Disability for a year now with Medicaid. On 11/1, my Medicare will become active (I got the card and stuff in the mail last month). Am also now working on a move so I can live closer to my boyfriend.  That would also be for 11/1 since the last day for the lease on my apartment is 10/31. It's a Bucket List kind of thing too. ~Lena.

Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2011 05:45PM Lena wrote: I'm 3 weeks out from a BMX, no recon. I was like you prior to going into the surgery -- scared shitless, and also thinking I was going to lose the whole summer to pain and disability downtime for recovery (I had my surgery 5/20/11). BUT it turned out to be way less bad than I thought it would be. The analogy I found best to describe it is this: I went in thinking I'd come out of the operation feeling like I'd been hit by a tractor-trailer, but instead I woke up feeling like I'd only been hit by a station wagon! LOL Of course, even if you're "only" hit by a station wagon, there is going to be SOME pain, SOME discomfort and a definite recovery curve. But I took Percocet for a week and a half (maybe almost 2 weeks), and that really helped things along. I didn't think the drains were so much painful as they were A PAIN (as in, a pain in the neck): you have to watch how you move and dress to carefully contain them and not snag their tubes on anything, and you have to empty/record the volume of the emptied fluid (I made a graph of mine: the curve is downward linear) and "strip" them twice a day too. My drains came out exactly a week after surgery, and shockingly taking them out and having their incisions dressed didn't hurt at all. I actually said "Oh, wow you got it out already?" to the nurse. And I'm the biggest sissy there is when it comes to pain: I find BLOOD DRAWS hurt, even when they "just" prick your finger to get the blood! So drains-out didn't hurt, but what DID hurt was when she took off all that damn itchy awful tape and steri-strips! OOOOOOUUUUUUCH! Also be careful about your arms. Even if you're NOT having any nodes removed (I didn't: "all" I had was a simple BMX), in the beginning, you're definitely going to have issues with range of motion on your mastectomy side (if unilateral) or both (if bilateral). Knowing this was going to happen, the week leading up to my surgery, I prepared in advance: cleaned the house, did the laundry, stocked up from the supermarket, and, most importantly: moved plenty of staple items (plates, bowls, coffee cups, drinkin glasses, coffee, tea, sugar, dry goods, canned food, anything that didn't need to be refrigerated or frozen) from overhead cabinets to the kitchen table top, so I'd be able to get at them easily. Important Nore: Do not even THINK of being able to get things out of overhead cabinets or off from high shelves for at least... um hmmmm...I still can't reach up there at 3 weeks, but I AM finally almost able to wash my hair without bending down -- so I'd guess maybe in about 2-3 months I'll be able to do the overhead cabinets again.. I even took extra "Bathroom Stuff" from the linen closet and moved it for easier access just in case I'd need it.  If you need or value your independence, I strongly suggest this sort of preparation. Having to serve meals on the coffee table in the living room because the kitchen table looks like a bomb went off on it is way worth it in terms of being ABLE to prepare simple meals and almost totally take care of yourself, by yourself.  Yes you heard that right -- I was able to feed BOTH me AND my boyfriend the day after the operation! (he got us pizza for dinner on the actual day of surgery once he brought me and my Percocet home). The only thing I NEEDED him to do for me the first few days after surgery was help me to get out of bed in the morning! Hahaha it was so weird -- there I was, totally able to prepare food and wash small amounts of dishes with no help at all, but I could NOT even get out of bed by myself! But on the fourth morning I think it was, I was able to get out of bed on my own. Recovery is perceptibly slow until you get your drains out. Once you get your drains out, you actually start noticing still slight, but definite day by day improvements, in terms of being able to do more things, like taking showers and getting dressed, or how active you can be,  I don't suggest being any more active than you HAVE to be, i.e., not too much beyond basic activities of daily living, but some is OK. When you start to get tired (or feel pain/tightness even if you took your pain meds), though, slack off, pronto. Pain pills might make you mentally lazy for awhile too.  Since I'm only moderately active normally when it comes to physical activity  -- I like to go for walks/run all my little in-town errands on foot, like to be able to do all my own housework with little or no help, plus container gardening on the deck (I did my planting the day after my drains came out!), but most of the things I REALLY enjoy involve me being seated in front of a computer or with a book in hand -- I'm sure my life was considerably less disrupted from this than someone who's a gym rat, has a very physically demanding job, or has to run after little kids, so for me, having to "slow down" to recover hasn't been too frustrating.  And, maybe you can take encouragement from THIS.....exactly two and a half weeks after my surgery, I was pleasantly surprised with my first post-BMX sex! Yeah, it was my boyfriend's idea, but that's only because of body image issues on my part (it's hard to feel sexy-confident when your chest looks like a science experiment gone awry), plus, I couldn't think of a position in which there would be no physical contact with my chest, which still felt a bit on the "raw" side (still does, too, but like the range of motion/how much I can do before I get tired things, I'm feeling slight but definite daily improvements with the rawness now too). But HE figured it out -- a way for us to do it with ZERO chest contact and maximal contact ELSEWHERE. ;-) ;-) ;-) woo-HOO!  (mechanical designers know how to make all the parts fit!) hee hee hee So that's how I'm coping, anyway. That, and with some physical therapy (started this week). Hope you find it helpful enough to not be so terrified. I'll never call it a party, but compared to chemotherapy and hormonal treatments -- mastectomy IS a walk in the park! All the best!

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2011 11:15AM Lena wrote: Cabmom, I had one of the OTHER SEs of Tamoxifen -- I ended up with a deep vein thrombosis -- Tamox increases the risk of blood clots as well as uterine cancer. I hope you're OK -- get the biopsy report yet? Back to our regularly scheduled conversation: I was 47 and in perimenopause when I was diagnosed. As in yes, I was technically premenopausal, but just beginning to START menopause.  From around 2-3 years prior to my diagnosis, my periods started going from almost clockwork regular in terms of both timing and flow amounts to all over the map -- I'd skip one, get some early, some late, some very heavy, some only spotty and various combinations of timing and flow which were so unpredictable I was buying that big box of 80 "mixed size" Tampax with all the different size tampons AND pads, both heavy "diaper" kind and very thin pantiliner kind -- I could have run a "Feminine Products Shop" right out of my linen closet! I wasn't having hot flashes or other menopausal symptoms but yeah the periods seemed to be on their way out. So when I was 47 and got my BC diagnosis, I was in the "I still menstruate but my periods are really bizarre" stage. I had had my last period prior to diagnosis, about 2-3 weeks before the diagnosis. Then I started chemo on April 9, 2009, and got a period, actually on time, and the ONLY "normal" one I'd had in YEARS, the week before my second chemo infusion. That period came on April 22, 2009 and was the last one I ever had. So even if my chemo regimen (6 rounds of TAC) wouldn't have caused PERMANENT menopause in a younger woman (or one who was still regular), it's no surprise it shut MY cycles down for good. I don't miss my period, but I hate everything ELSE about menopause. I used to think that not having a period anymore would be the one and ONLY good thing about getting old (which I really didn't want to do anyway), so when the onc and chemo nurse said I'd probably go all the way into permanent menopause from chemo, I wasn't upset because I didn't want to have children and I hated having periods anyway. I never even thought of the OTHER aspects of menopause, probably since I wasn't having any of them so they didn't even occur to me. Well, with my 20/20 hindsight, if it was possible, I would gladly take the periods back because I positively HATE all the other stuff about menopause worse than I hated having my period! Chemo, Tamoxifen (for the 5 months I took it -- onc took me off when he found the blood clot on one of my scans) and AIs have given me horrible hot flashes, painfully stiff hips and knees, insomnia and depression (which I have to take meds for), and hurting feet and hands. I'd rather bleed and feel like hell for 4-5 days a month and then be good the rest of the time, than feel the way I do now ALL THE TIME, day in and day out, no respite, and the only "cure" being to die of cancer -- like a 90-YEAR-OLD!! and I'm "only" about to turn 50 in a couple of months. BEING OLD SUCKS! GRRR! >:-P

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2011 04:14PM Lena wrote: I guess everyone's body is different, Sue. My "oligometastatic" bone met was to my left iliac bone and it was treated successfully (for now, anyway) with chemotherapy and anti-hormonal drugs (first Tamoxifen then AIs). However, I'm currently in the midst of rads to my entire chest wall/supraclavicular nodes post BMX and post-removal of some skin mets which cropped up on my right ribcage this spring. Unfortunately my radiation SEs are worse than cafelovr's -- terrrible coughing fits (since some of the radiation is getting to my lungs even though they don't need it), fatigue, and now red blistering itchy painful "sunburn" skin...and as of today I've only had 25 of the 33 treatments I'm supposed to have! :-{ (26 is tomorrow).... Sue, I'm sorry but the only thing I can tell you is that this all SUCKS! Both chemotherapy and AIs are WAY WORSE than radiation, as bad as radiation is! I'm so sorry for you, Sue.

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2011 06:57PM - edited Jun 3, 2011 07:00PM by Lena Yes you can, Bobbiejo. I did major shopping and stocking up and "preparing" prior to starting chemo so I only had to buy perishables (milk and eggs, sometimes cheese or yogurt or pudding too) during my entire time on chemo. Good thing, since I was one of the ones whose fatigue was constant and crushing -- I don't think I had ANY "good" days at ALL after my 3rd round (I got 6 rounds of TAC) -- but, I was still able to drive to the store to get the milk and eggs even when I felt like complete crap.  My cancer center's social services department had a transportation van which patients could sign up for to get rides to and from treatment sessions and oncologist appointments, so I signed up for that and always had rides for infusions, Neulasta shots, blood tests and checkups. Also, prior to chemo, I found and switched to a local pharmacy who would deliver too, in the event that my chemo nurse or oncologist would call in medication at a time I was too sick or tired to go pick it up myself.

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2011 09:57AM - edited Mar 15, 2011 10:01AM by Lena No, hadn't heard of lumpectomy on Stage IV patients at all until seeing this thread. In fact, the oncologist who diagnosed me (with Stage IV at the gate) and began my treatment told me, AFTER I had finished the chemo, which I had done for the sole reason of shrinking my ginormous tumor enough to make a mastectomy POSSIBLE -- that MASTECTOMY was not standard of care for Stage IV. Lumpectomy was never even mentioned to me, probably because for MY treatment plan it would have been completely irrelevant: my entire right breast had been transformed from a breast with cancer in it to a cancer with breast in it! Anyway, this doctor said that for Stage IV patients, the only time it was standard to perform a mastectomy would be if tumor was breaking out from the skin of the breast, which causes painful, oozing, smelly sores -- a real mess -- and I didn't have that problem. So no yucky escaped tumor = no breast surgery for me. At our last appointment (March 2nd) my new oncologist, however, was beginning to sing a different tune (with regards to mastectomy, I mean), at least as of our last appointment, but she said she wanted to see the result of my next scans first before she said any more about it. As of now, however, I'm going to guess that between my upcoming scan result and the addition to a very recent development (as of two nights ago) that she'll probably sing this same tune a little louder, with or without some harmonies I may consider too dissonant for my ears -- but that would be a subject for another thread. In the meanwhile, I hope you're feeling as good as you can possibly feel!
